questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency because of fever, productive cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain (worse on inspiration) for the past 4 days. He has refractory Schizophrenia. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Crackles and bronchial breath sounds are heard on auscultation of the left lung. Lab studies show: Hb: 13.5 mg/dl TLC: 1100/mm3 Segmented Neutrophil: 5% Eosinophils: 0% Lymphocytes: 93% Monocytes: 2% Platelet Counts 260000/mm3 Which of the following medications is this patient most likely taking?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Clozapine This patient has refractory schizophrenia . He now has agranulocytosis which likely led to an infection. Clozapine is used primarily for resistant schizophrenia (to first-line pharmacological therapy). While it is highly effective in the treatment of schizophrenia, it has serious adverse effects , which can include the life-threatening agranulocytosis seen in this patient. About 1–2% of all patients who begin taking clozapine eventually develop agranulocytosis (usually in the first months of treatment ), though this risk falls substantially after the first year. The most common symptoms of agranulocytosis are oral ulcerations, fever, malaise , and increased susceptibility to infections such as pneumonia.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic that can cause sedation , metabolic syndrome, hyperglycemia , and weight gain. This patient's agranulocytosis is not a typical adverse effect. Option: C. Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is commonly used as a first-line treatment for schizophrenia. Adverse effects include weight gain , hyperglycemia, and orthostatic hypotension , but it does not typically cause agranulocytosis. Furthermore, it is rarely used for refractory schizophrenia, making it an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms. Option: D. Haloperidol is a high-potency antipsychotic that can cause extrapyramidal and anticholinergic adverse effects , neither of which are seen in this patient. This patient's agranulocytosis is not an expected adverse effect.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female presented with visual hallucinations for the past 9 months and delusions for the past 7 months. She was diagnosed to have schizophrenia and was started on an antipsychotic drug. Later the patient developed high-grade fever and rigidity. Blood investigation showed leukocytosis and an increase in CPK – 3 levels (>1000). What is the 1st step of management in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stop the anti-psychotic The patient has developed Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome . It is a side effect of antipsychotic drugs. It is characterized by high-grade fever, rigidity, increased TLC, and CPK-3 MM levels (>1000) . It is managed by stopping the antipsychotic first. IV dantrolene is the drug of choice . Bromocriptine and amantadine are other drugs used.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. In NMS antipsychotic is stopped completely. Option: C. IV dantrolene is the drug of choice for NMS, but not the 1st step. Option: D. Bromocriptine, amantadine are other drugs used in NMS.
